subject: Programming
title: Immutable Data Structures
description: A micro-lesson that makes Immutable Data Structures usable.

hook.text: What if you never modified data â€” only created new versions? Bugs from shared state disappear.

buildup.text: Immutable structures create new copies on every change. The old version remains untouched.

discovery.text: Structural sharing means copies reuse most of the original. Only changed parts are new.

twist.text: Immutability uses more memory and feels wasteful. But it eliminates entire categories of concurrency bugs.

climax.text: React, Redux, and functional languages embrace immutability for safer, more predictable programs.

punchline.text: Never change the original. Create a better version.

quiz.question: How do immutable structures avoid wasting memory?
